Crime_Name: Refugee Claim and Pre-Removal Risk Assessment
Legal_Issue: Did the PRRA officer err in assessing the applicant's risk upon return to Brazil and using extrinsic evidence?
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant claimed generalized human rights violations; PRRA officer used publicly available, confirmatory extrinsic evidence
Decision_Outcome: PRRA officer concluded Brazil offers adequate state protection despite high crime rates
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate personalized persecution and lack of state protection
Legal_Rule: State protection need not be perfect, only adequate
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness simpliciter for mixed questions of fact and law
Procedural_Issue: Use of extrinsic evidence by PRRA officer
Grounds_for_Claim: Risk upon return to Brazil due to generalized violence and human rights violations
Outcome_on_Merits: Application for refugee protection and PRRA denied
Key_Evidence_Considered: Generalized crime rates in Brazil, publicly available reports on state protection capacity
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Canadian jurisprudence on refugee claims and PRRA
Applicant_Challenge: PRRA officer’s risk assessment and use of extrinsic evidence
Legal_Rule_Source: Federal Court jurisprudence on standard of review and state protection
Evidence_Type: Extrinsic evidence – publicly available country condition reports
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of PRRA decision and referral back for re-determination
Legal_Provision: Sections of IRPA relating to PRRA and risk assessment
Claimant_Status: Failed refugee claimant, subject to removal
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Lack of credible basis for fear of persecution upon return
Pending_Relief_or_Application: Permanent residence application and PRRA were previously denied
Governing_Rule: Reasonableness standard applies to PRRA decisions
